item.title: Obama Meets Raúl Castro, Making History
item.description: President Obama came to the Summit of the Americas in Panama determined to defuse a generations-old regional dispute over Cuba’s exclusion from the meeting.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:description: President Obama met with President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil on Saturday. She is scheduled to visit the White House in June.

item.title: A Top Islamist Is Executed by Bangladesh
item.description: Bangladesh on Saturday executed a senior Islamist party official convicted of crimes against humanity during the country’s 1971 independence war with Pakistan, two officials and two television stations said.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Legacy of a South Korean Ferry Sinking
item.description: A year after a South Korean ferry sank, killing more than 300 people, numerous government regulatory changes are taking effect — and drawing some criticism.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Hanil Blue Narae, which sails between Jeju and Wando in South Korea.

item.title: Empty Ebola Clinics in Liberia Are Seen as Misstep in U.S. Relief Effort
item.description: After spending hundreds of millions of dollars and deploying nearly 3,000 troops, only 28 Ebola patients have been treated at the 11 treatment units built by the United States military in Liberia.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A drop in Ebola cases in Liberia lessened the need for treatment units such as this Defense Ministry center.

item.title: Maoist Rebels Kill at Least 7 Police Officers in India
item.description: Gunmen ambushed a unit of police officers who were conducting a mission in Chhattisgarh State.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: Separatists Claim Attack That Killed 20 in Pakistan
item.description: Separatists claimed responsibility for an attack on construction workers in Baluchistan Province, which has simmered with an insurgency for decades.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: U.N. Official Visits Syria to Press Urgency of Besieged Refuge Camp
item.description: The “urgent mission” by Pierre Krähenbühl was intended to call attention to what is seen as impending calamity at the Yarmouk camp, where some 18,000 Palestinian and Syrian civilians are trapped.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A man searched rubble last week in the Yarmouk refugee camp near Damascus, Syria. Some 18,000 civilians are trapped there by clashes between government and Islamic State forces.

item.title: From A to Z (Asteroids to Zombies), the British Just Want the Facts
item.description: A decade ago, the doors were swung wide open to allow public scrutiny into agencies, bureaus and councils, and the result has been both gratifying and slightly alarming.
item.dc:creator: BRYONY CLARKE
item.media:credit: Marco Kesseler for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lord David Clark of Windermere, the cabinet minister in the government of Tony Blair who drafted the Freedom of Information bill, said the law was long overdue and a success.

item.title: New China-Led Bank Pledges to Fend Off Graft
item.description: China’s new development bank will strive to be corruption free, maintain environmentally sound policies and work with a streamlined bureaucracy, the interim head of the institution said.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Jin Liqun is the interim leader of the Asian investment bank.

item.title: American Among Nearly 40 Sentenced to Life in Prison for Egypt Protests
item.description: Mohamed Soltan was sentenced to life imprisonment for supporting an Islamist protest against the military ouster of President Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood in 2013.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and JARED MALSIN
item.media:description: Egyptian policemen guarded the defendants’ cage in a Cairo courtroom on Saturday at a verdict hearing for nearly 40 people in an antigovernment protest case.

item.title: Tibetan Nun Calling for End to China Rule and Dalai Lama’s Return Sets Self on Fire
item.description: The nun, Yeshi Khando, was the 138th Tibetan to self-immolate since 2009 in Tibetan regions ruled by China, according to the International Campaign for Tibet.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Handshake for Obama and Raúl Castro of Cuba
item.description: The expected encounter held deep significance during a gathering of regional leaders, as President Obama’s move to ease tensions with Cuba has overshadowed the official agenda.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:credit: Panama Presidency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Obama greeted his Cuban counterpart, Raúl Castro, before the opening ceremony of the VII Summit of the Americas in Panama City on Friday.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: North Korea’s Real Lessons for Iran
item.description: The ’94 nuclear deal didn’t last, but that doesn’t make it a failure.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT L. GALLUCCI and JOEL S. WIT

item.title: China Is Said to Use Powerful New Weapon to Censor Internet
item.description: The tool allows Beijing to intercept foreign web traffic and inject malicious code, and it could have more powerful capabilities.
item.dc:creator: NICOLE PERLROTH
item.media:description: A tool researchers call the Great Cannon is said to have redirected traffic intended for the Chinese search engine Baidu.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Don’t Block Remittances to Somalia
item.description: To bring stability, the U.S. must help migrants send money home.
item.dc:creator: KEITH ELLISON

item.title: U.N. Warns of Deepening Crisis in Syrian Refugee Camp Overrun by Militants
item.description: United Nations officials said Friday that the siege of Yarmouk, the devastated refugee camp in Syria where 18,000 severely malnourished and dehydrated Palestinians are trapped, had only gotten worse.
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:description: A Palestinian fighter in the Yarmouk camp, south of Damascus, on Thursday. About 18,000 people are trapped there.

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: 3 Ex-Lawmakers Arrested in Corruption Case
item.description: The federal police arrested three former lawmakers who are suspected of involvement in a corruption scheme at the state-run oil giant Petrobras. They are the first politicians to be arrested in the scandal.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Spanish Judge Accuses Moroccan Former Officials of Genocide in Western Sahara
item.description: A Spanish judge rules in a case linked to torture and killings of the Sahrawi people from 1976 to 1991.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: World Briefing: Afghanistan: 13 Civilians Killed in 2 Separate Blasts
item.description: A suicide car bomber attacked a convoy of American troops in eastern Afghanistan, and in another eastern province, 10 people were killed when their minivan hit a roadside bomb.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: France: India Agrees to Buy 36 Rafale Fighter Jets
item.description: The transaction was announced Friday by Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India during a state visit to France, even as the two countries continue to work on a stalled larger deal.
item.dc:creator: NICOLA CLARK
